text: Family Member: Xtandi, okay. Doctor: and then we’ll throw on a second medication. Patient: What are the names of the other two drugs? Doctor: No names. All letters and numbers. Family Member: Good. Doctor: Poof! You just turn into a guinea pig again. You were there before, but yeah. I think that’s the hard part. It’s umm, you know, they don’t give names unless it’s moving along the path of development. Umm. And then uh, it’s sorta like you don’t name your pet…you don’t think you’re gonna keep it. I don’t know. Patient: Ahhh. Doctor: But, it’s usually letters and numbers. Ummm. But, they work in a class of drugs that we think are highly active in prostate cancer, so it’s about five different drugs that are in this space, targeting the same pathway. So, we just don’t know which one has an opening. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: And, when would that start? Doctor: M___ will tell us, but probably, you know, obviously in the new year, and it maybe second or third week… Patient: Well, they took seven vials of blood…

text: Family Member: Spine, ribs, and shoulder? (pause11sec) Doctor: Yeah. The one, the one thing we see also with, we’ve seen with the testosterone, is something called a flair. Meaning spots are there- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - but we don’t see them very well, and then we give a drug like that, they can get more intense so they show up. And I think these are spots that are, you know, been there for probably a year or two just below the radar. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It’s just a matter of, you know, we’re seeing them now. Uh, and whether the testosterone helped to see them better, that’s what we see with some other guys. So, uh, but I think certainly there’s enough there that we’ve got to keep- Family Member: Do something else? Yeah. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Alright. Doctor: So I will call you probably Friday- Patient: Okay. Doctor: With some information. Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member: Right? Am I wrong there? Doctor: Well, it isn’t. You know what it is? It creates an unhealthy environment for you. And for all the other stuff I may potentially have to do for you, to you, however we want to say that, I need you functioning and that diabetes can’t be in my way. Gosh darn it. Doctor: Yeah. Plus unregulated, and I mean this up and down, your body just doesn’t like it. So the steady state might be alright at a hemoglobin A one C of seven two but your every day, what you get is tired. You crash. You go back up. You’re good. You crash. You’re tired. You come back up. That’s not, boom, okay. Patient: So then like I again explained to Dr. W___ about my, about my fatigue. Doctor: Um hum. Yes. Patient: Is my lack of uninterrupted sleep. I just don’t get it. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I don’t get – there’s never a night that I get three or four hours uninterrupted sleep. Doctor: Cause you’re peeing? Patient: Um, yes. Doctor: Yeah. So what time do you stop drinking? Patient: Every time I get up, I drink some more water. (Laughter)

text: Patient: I get it. Doctor: It’s the cancer that’s doing all bad things. I care. Family Member: Right. Doctor: The cancer doesn’t care so we need to be ahead of it. Patient: I’m with you. Doctor: Well, we’re going to find out to see if it’s waking up. You’ve had everything under the sun thus far. Family Member: Right. Doctor: We will continue to be as aggressive. text: Patient: Mhm. Doctor: -and then decide if you know you're even eligible, or that you're even interested after you review it one more time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then if it's good, then they sign you and then we go, and if you're like eh I don’t know, and then we think of something else. No pressure. Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: All right. Patient: All right. So this is the best. This is the best option that you're thinking right now. Doctor: Mhm. Yeah. It keeps you on things that you haven't really broken through, but your pills are starting to do this. They’re starting to tread water. And I'm like, “Hold up!” before you start to sink. Let me see if we can throw a lifeline. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So a lot of the prostate cancer trials are like that now. So we're like, I'm okay. I'm okay. And then you’re like uh oh I’m starting to fade. And so we have all these new pills that are like, wait- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: - I'm gonna come and help you. Patient: Okay, so.

text: Patient: So is it in somewhere in comparison…? Well I guess they’re two independent things then. Doctor: It’s two, it’s two independent things. You are a extremely low risk gist tumor. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And and the risk is not determined by the size. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s determined by um how rapidly the cells are dividing, so there’s something that’s called a mitosis. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: A mitosis means however the cell’s dividing. And you have like the very lowest mitotic rate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So your gist basically it’s it’s a really dumb one; it doesn’t really know how to metastasize. So when you’ve got a cancer, you’d rather have a dumb one than a smart one. You had a really dumb gist tumor. But you’ve kind of got a smarter prostate cancer. So the gist tumor I think is extremely unlikely… Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: …to spread to a lymphnode although it is theoretically possible. But what is far more likely given the fact that you have a prostate cancer with you know high Gleason score and a PSA that is rising… Patient: Uh hum.

text: Patient: Oh. Doctor: We made a deal with one of the drug companies who makes the immune therapy. Family Member: Well, they are good for something. Doctor: So, my advice right now, we don’t do anything. You’re responding to hormone treatment. Let’s keep going. And, at some point, we don’t know if this has anything to do with BRCA2 or whatever, but at some point, you’re going to become resistant. Everybody does. And, at that point, we, we will discuss what to do next. And, normally, Patient: So --- Doctor: What to do next – I’m sorry – is to give you another hormone therapy. But, in your case, what, what we might do next is consider like, a trial where we use one of these DNA repair blockers. Um. And, we have two of them open right now that you would be eligible for. So. So, you know, the issue with you is I don’t want to talk about those yet because you might respond to hormone therapy for five more years. (laughs) Patient: Yeah. It, it was two hundred and fifty dollars. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Two hundred and— Family Member: It’s okay. We got to test twenty people. We’ll take the reduced price. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Well. If, but, if there isn’t – Family Member: Oh, we’re still going to do it

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
